Title: Differential Effects of Meditation on Relationship Quality
Abstract:
Abstract
Differential Effects of Meditation on Relationship Quality
By Brighid Malloy Kleinman
Relationships are one of the most crucial parts of life and a
highly studied subject
in psychology. Yet psychologists still have difficulty explaining
how to help people gain
and maintain close, positive relationships. The present study aims
to investigate whether
an existing intrapersonal health strategy, meditation, can also
help interpersonal health.
Specifically, psychological and neurobiological evidence suggests
that compassion
mediation in particular may be particularly relevant to close
relationships. Based on
evidence suggesting that compassion - the desire to free others
from suffering - is
strongly related to relationship quality, it is hypothesized that
the cultivation of
compassion through meditation will enhance self-reported
relationship quality.
Furthermore, it is hypothesized that interpersonal (i.e.,
compassion, empathy, and
forgiveness) and intrapersonal (i.e., emotion regulation and
coping) variables will
mediate the relationship between compassion meditation and
relationship quality.

Title:
Phenomenology of God: Phenomenological Foundations of Metaphysical
Conception
Abstract:
This thesis begins by setting out to explore the question "What
is God?" Realizing that both the term and the concept of "God"
exist within particular socio-religious contexts (and even within
such contexts, there are disconnects between conceptions of "God"),
the question could not be approached as posed. Instead, the
question had to be subsumed within the larger sphere of
metaphysical conception in general. Metaphysical conception, as
broadly defined in this thesis, includes such conceptions as
Platonic "forms," ideals such as Love and Liberty, utopian and
dystopian conceptions, absolute "being" or "essencelessness," the
absolute nature of the self, and so forth. Simply, this thesis sets
out to explore how it is that we hold metaphysical conceptions at
all, given that our perceptual experience is limited to physical
objects of perception. In order to approach this problem, this
thesis employs the phenomenological perspectives of twentieth
century philosophers Maurice Merleau-Ponty and Martin Heidegger, as
well as contemporary phenomenologists John Russon and Kym Maclaren,
as its theoretical lens with which to explore the nature of
subjective perception and how subjective perception lends itself
toward metaphysical conception.
The first two chapters of this thesis perform phenomenological
reflection on the appearance of objects and persons. Taken
together, these two initial chapters iterate the phenomenological
concept that objects of perception, from the most mundane inanimate
objects to behaviorally complex persons, do not appear as static,
independent entities; rather, phenomena always appear as
spatio-temporally oriented and open to inexhaustible appropriation.
The "horizons" of phenomenal appearance are fundamental to
perception and highlight the way in which phenomena necessarily
appear as resistant to complete appropriation or definition. The
examples of language and art are used as two examples of which the
horizons of phenomenal appearance are explicit. Finally, with
twentieth century theologian Karl Rahner's concept of "man as
transcendent being," this thesis emphasizes the a priori
structure of man's very being-in-the-world as open. The concluding
claim of this thesis is that the phenomenological horizons so
fundamental to man's perceptual inherence in the world are the
basis of metaphysical conception.
Table of Contents:
Introduction: The Problem of Metaphysical Conception 2 -- I.

Title: THE VOLTAGE-GATED SODIUM CHANNEL SCN1A AND EPILEPSY
Abstract:
Mutations in the voltage-gated sodium channel SCN1A, encoding the Nav1.1 protein, are with two
human epilepsy disorders: Genetic Epilepsy with Febrile Seizure
Plus (GEFS+) and Dravet Syndrome (DS). Electrophysiological
analysis of cortical and hippocampal neurons from mouse models of
GEFS+ and DS led to the hypothesis that these disorders arise from
reduced excitability of inhibitory GABAergic interneurons. To test
this hypothesis, I examined the effect of preferentially deleting
Scn1a from either inhibitory interneurons or
excitatory pyramidal cells in the forebrain. I found that the
heterozygous deletion of Scn1a from interneurons
(mainly parvalbumin) resulted in spontaneous seizures and increased
seizure susceptibility. In contrast, seizure thresholds were not
significantly altered following the deletion of Scn1a from pyramidal cells.
Due to the frequent occurrence of early-life febrile seizures
(FS) in patients with SCN1A mutations, I also
evaluated mice expressing the human SCN1A GEFS+
mutation R1648H for susceptibility to hyperthermia-induced
seizures. Specifically, I compared the average seizure induction
temperature, seizure latency, duration and severity between mutant
and wildtype (WT) littermates. I found that the severity of the
induced febrile seizure was age dependent; however, the other
parameters examined did not vary with age. In addition, I
investigated whether prolonged early-life FS influence adult
seizure phenotypes. To achieve this, I developed two paradigms; one
modeling a single prolonged FS (PLFS), and the other modeling
repetitive FS (A/PLFS). Mice subjected to each paradigm were
evaluated for seizure susceptibility and spontaneous seizure
frequency at months post FS induction. Of important clinical
relevance, I found that early-life prolonged FS reduces seizure
thresholds and increases the frequency of spontaneous seizures
during adulthood.
Many patients with SCN1A mutations do not
achieve adequate seizure control with available medications and
there is an urgent need to develop better treatment strategies. As
a result, I evaluated the efficacy of the ketogenic diet (KD) as a
potential non-pharmacological treatment for DS and GEFS+. I found
that the KD was able to elevate seizure thresholds in mouse models
of GEFS+ and DS to levels that were not statistically different
from WT littermates. Lastly, I determined if genetic factors might
contribute to the efficacy of the KD. I observed that the effect of
the diet on seizure thresholds varied between different inbred
strains of mice, suggesting that genetic factors are likely to
influence efficacy in the human population.

Title:
Selling to the Souls of Black Folk: Atlanta, Reverend J.M. Gates,
the Phonograph, and the Transformation of African American
Protestantism and Culture, 1910-1945.
Abstract:
Abstract
Selling to the Souls of Black Folk:
Atlanta, Reverend J.M. Gates, the Phonograph, and the
Transformation of African
American Protestantism and Culture, 1910-1945 .
By Lerone A. Martin
There is much work in the discipline of American religious history
that chronicles
the significance of mass mediums such as print, radio, film,
television, and the Internet in
the practice(s) of Protestant Christianity. However, the field has
been slow to recognize
the phonograph as an equally vital tool within these traditions.
Selling to the Souls of
Black Folk takes up this neglected task by historically
tracing the phenomenon of African
American Protestant clergy utilizing the phonograph for the mass
transmission of their
sermons during the first half of the Twentieth century. This
unprecedented use of mass
communication and religious commodification enabled black clergy,
who were largely
marginalized from radio, to become cultural celebrities, alongside
popular music artists,
within African American communities. Leading record labels recorded
these spiritual
commodities and advertised them in black newspapers, posters,
handbills, department
stores, mail-order catalogues, record label shops, and furniture
stores. As a result, the
placement of these sermons on the market shelf significantly
altered the substance and
form of black religious practices. This story examines several of
the approximately one
hundred African American phonograph sermon recorders prior to World
War II.
However, Atlanta and the city's Reverend J.M. Gates, the most
prolific phonograph
sermon recorder, are the anchors of this historical study. This
conceptual lynchpin allows
for a concentrated analysis of how the emergence and popularity of
phonograph sermons
both reflected and facilitated shifts within African American
Protestantism. Selling to the
Souls of Black Folk, therefore, offers an important
historical account that is essential to
understanding the major trends and practices that undergird
contemporary American
Protestantism and religious broadcasting.
Selling to the Souls of Black Folk
Atlanta, Reverend J.M. Gates, the Phonograph, and the
Transformation of African
American Protestantism and Culture, 1910-1945
By
Lerone A. Martin,
M.Div., Princeton Theological Seminary, 2005
Advisor: Gary Laderman, Ph.D
A dissertation submitted to the Faculty of the
James T. Laney School of Graduate Studies of Emory University
In partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of
Doctor of Philosophy
In the Graduate Division of Religion
American Religious Cultures, 2011.

Title: Role of TMS1/ASC in Breast Epithelial Anoikis and Migration
Abstract:
Cellular detachment from the extracellular matrix (ECM) induces
a form of
apoptosis, referred to as "anoikis." Most cancer cells are
resistant to anoikis and survive
independently of ECM interactions. Previously, we identified a
pro-apoptotic gene,
TMS1 that is epigenetically silenced in breast cancers.
Overexpression of TMS1 is
sufficient to induce procaspase-8 cleavage in breast cells in the
absence of death receptor-
ligand interactions. Additionally, TMS1 aggregates to form 'specks'
in some apoptotic
cells, although the function of this structure remains unclear.
Here we established a role
for TMS1 in anoikis and uncovered a nonapoptotic role for TMS1 in
cell migration. We
show that cellular detachment induces TMS1 expression. In addition,
we find that
silencing TMS1 confers resistance to anoikis through a delay in
procaspase-8 cleavage
and accumulation of BimEL. ERK1/2 signaling negatively regulates
BimEL
accumulation during detachment. We found that silencing TMS1
resulted in persistent
ERK1/2 signaling during anoikis. We conclude that loss of TMS1
promotes resistance to
anoikis in part through misregulation of ERK1/2 signaling and
suppression of BimEL
accumulation. During the course of these studies a nonapoptotic
role for procaspase-8 in
adhesion and migration was elucidated by many groups. The next
phase of our research
was aimed towards deciphering a role for TMS1 upstream of
procaspase-8 in anoikis.
Thus, we next investigated a nonapoptotic role for TMS1 in these
processes. We found
that adhesion to fibronectin induced the redistribution of TMS1 to
barrel-like structures.
Silencing TMS1 delayed FAK and ERK1/2 signaling in response to
integrin-fibronectin
interactions. Phosphorylated FAK and centrosomal markers
colocalized with TMS1 at
barrel-like structures in a subset of cells. Through functional
analyses, we further
demonstrated a role for TMS1 in cell migration. These data
suggest that an association of
TMS1 with centrosomes results in the formation of a critical
signaling center that may
regulate migration. In conclusion, our data demonstrate distinct
functions for TMS1 in
anoikis and migration. Overall, results from these studies have
increased our
understanding of the intricate functions TMS1 exhibits in
epithelial cells and has
provided great insight into the consequences of aberrant
methylation and silencing of
TMS1 observed in many cancers.

Title:
A Spatial and Geostatistical Analysis of Polybrominated Biphenyl
Exposure in Michigan
Abstract:
In a study of geographic distribution of human exposure to
polybrominated biphenyl in the Michigan PBB Registry, following a
contamination incident in 1973, PBB quarantined farms are
investigated for their potential as sites of environmental
contamination and continued human exposure to PBB. Spatial
distribution maps were created to describe human PBB exposure from
1976-1979, quarantined farms, estimated decay rates, and breast
cancer rates by county. Univariate geostatistical analyses assessed
global and local autocorrelation. Bivariate geostatistical analyses
evaluated global and local autocorrelation of human PBB exposure,
estimated decay rates, and breast cancer rates with the number of
quarantined farms in Michigan counties. A land use analysis
measured the area of agricultural land in 1978 developed into urban
land use in 1992, in counties with the highest number of
quarantined farms. No significant global autocorrelation was found
across the state of Michigan for any variable, with the exception
of mean breast cancer rates. Results of the local univariate
analyses indicated differential distribution of PBB exposure. Three
major areas associated with higher human PBB exposure were located
around the city of Grand Rapids, in the thumb of Michigan's lower
peninsula, and in the southwestern corner of the state. Bivariate
significant autocorrelation with quarantined farms was found at
these same locations. The land use analyses revealed counties
located around the city of Grand Rapids had the greatest total land
area transition from agriculture to urban land use. In the thumb of
the state, significant bivariate autocorrelation identified an area
of high of quarantined farms and slower decay rates. In conclusion,
this study identifies areas of Michigan associated with higher
human exposure to PBB in 1976-1979. This analysis suggests that
counties around the city of Grand Rapids have a higher potential
for continued human exposure to PBB from quarantined farms and that
slower rates of decay found in the thumb of the state, can
potentially be attributed to continued human exposure from
quarantined farms. The implications of these findings can be better
understood through environmental sampling, more detailed land use
data analyses, and continued spatial analyses of point
locations.

Title:
Characterizing Exposure to Persistent Organic Pollutants in the
Michigan Chemical Corporation and Pine River Community
Abstract:
Purpose: After the industrial accident in
1973 in Michigan exposed thousands of people to polybrominated
biphenyls (PBB), the Michigan PBB Registry was started to track the
exposed to conduct research on health outcomes. In the 1990s those
who were former chemical workers of Michigan Chemical Corporation
and their families were dropped from the registry due to multiple
exposures. In 2014, former PBB Registry participants were invited
to re-join the Registry. This study aims to characterize the
chemical workers, their families, and others living in the
St.Louis/Pine River area who may have been exposed to PBB and other
persistent organic pollutants.
Methods: Blood samples were collected from
participants in December, 2013 and in March, 2014. Serum was
analyzed for PBB153, DDT and DDE isomers, and HBB.
Participant's serum concentrations were coupled with
questionnaire data about their demographic
classifications. Univariate statistics were used to describe
the study cohort's chemical distributions. The study
cohort distributions were compared with NHANES
2003-2004 distributions as a baseline indicator of national
background concentrations. Linear regression was performed on
natural log transformed PBB153 and p,p-DDE concentrations as the
dependent outcomes with covariates of the different
classifications.
Results: Chemical workers had significantly
higher PBB153 concentrations than the other three classifications
of participants that stayed significant when adjusted for age and
gender. Family members of chemical workers had significantly higher
PBB153 concentrations than the other two classifications of
participants that stayed significant when adjusted for age and
gender. Age was the only strong predictor of p,p-DDE
concentrations. All participants measured below the level of
detection for DDT isomers, o,p-DDE, and HBB. The overall
distribution of the study cohort had elevated PBB153 concentrations
compared with the NHANES 2003-2004 data.
Conclusion: This study highlights the need
for chemical workers and their families to be included back into
the Michigan PBB Registry, as they represent a highly exposed
population to PBB. Future studies should focus on linking
environmental sampling of persistent organic pollutants in St.
Louis/Pine River to human exposures -
including reassessing DDT/DDE/DDD as well as other compounds
such as PCB, PBDE, and dieldrin.

Title: Moral Distress in Respiratory Therapists
Abstract:
Abstract
Youth sexual and reproductive health in Bosnia and
Herzegovina:
Informing intervention strategies using quantitative methods
by Glen R. Abedi
Youth sexual and reproductive health represents an area of
healthcare that is in particular need of
development in Bosnia-Herzegovina. However, little research on this
subject has been conducted to date
to guide policy and programming. CARE Northwest Balkans, a regional
subsidiary of CARE
International, completed a quantitative survey on youth sexual and
reproductive health in Bosnia-
Herzegovina in 2006. Respondents consisted(Mann, Drucker,
Tarantola, & McCabe, 1994) of university
students above the age of 18. They answered questions about their
behaviors and attitudes associated with
sexual and reproductive health (SRH) and related behaviors.
The largest ethnic group represented in the sample was Serbs
(71.56%), followed by Bosniaks
(23.85%). The median age of respondents was 22.21 years. Only 5.50%
of respondents reported ever
having been tested for sexually transmitted infections (STI)
although 69.72% reported having engaged in
sexual intercourse in the previous year. The most popular sources
of information on sexual and
reproductive health were TV & radio, printed materials, and
school. The effectiveness of these sources of
information as avenues for public health communications remains
unclear.

Title:
Depression Medication Use Among Women Exposed to Polybrominated
Biphenyls, Michigan 1997-2006
Abstract:
Abstract
Depression Medication Use Among Women Exposed to Polybrominated
Biphenyls,
Michigan 1997-2006
Objective: This study examined the potential
association of dietary exposure to
polybrominated biphenyls (PBBs), a brominated flame retardant, and
self-reported use of
depression medication among women. PBBs belong to a class of
chemical that have
demonstrated disruption of endocrine systems and pathway. Onset of
depression may be
due to many factors but gender differences in prevalence and the
vulnerability of women
during reproductive lifetime events, such as menses, pregnancy, the
postpartum period
and menopause, suggest the involvement of reproductive
hormones.
Methods: Women exposed to PBB in the early 1970s were
enrolled in a population-based
cohort and provided blood serum samples to ascertain PBB
concentrations in the body.
This study includes 901 women who participated in interviews
conducted in 1997-1998
or in 2003-2006. Information collected during the interviews
included demographics,
lifestyle, medical history, reproductive history, and exposure
history. Logistic regression
models for use of depression medication in the year prior to
interview used enrollment
PBB exposure and current PBB exposure. A general linear mixed decay
model using
enrollment PBB concentrations estimated current PBB concentrations.
All models were
adjusted for PCB levels at enrollment, age at interview, history of
thyroid disease, history
of cancer, BMI at interview, smoking status, and use of hormone
replacement therapy.
Results: Depression medication use in the 12 months
prior to interview was reported for
133 women, with an overall prevalence of 14.8%. This study did not
find an association
between exposure to PBB and depression medication usage among
women, however
among current or former smokers with PBB exposure an increased
likelihood of
depression medication use was observed compared to non-smokers with
low PBB
exposure. (Current PBB <0.85 ppb: OR 1.57, 95% CI 1.06-2.32;
Current PBB 0.85 ≤ 2.4
ppb: OR 1.85, 95% CI 1.00-3.43; Enrollment PBB ≤1 ppb: OR
1.56, 95% CI 1.05-2.30;
Enrollment PBB 1 - 4 ppb: OR 1.86, 95% CI 1.01-3.41)
Conclusion: This study suggests that PBB exposure
increases the chance of depression
among women who are current or former smokers. Additional research
should explore
the interaction between PBBs and smoking and depression associated
with altered
hormone pathways.

Title:
Characterizing Neighborhood Demographics, Socioeconomic
Conditions, Water and Sanitation Infrastructure and Practices, and
Fecal Contamination in Four Low-Income Neighborhoods in Accra,
Ghana
Abstract:
Introduction: Rapidly-growing, low-income urban environments
often have poor water and sanitation services that can lead to
exposure to fecal contamination in the public domain. This study
describes and compares the demographics, socioeconomic conditions,
and physical characteristics of four low-income urban neighborhoods
in Accra, Ghana. Water, sanitation and hygiene conditions and
practices and environmental fecal contamination levels were
compared.
Methods: Household surveys were administered to residents in
four study neighborhoods (Alajo, Bukom, Old Fadama, Shiabu) in
Accra, Ghana. Residents were asked about demographic,
infrastructural characteristics, sanitation practices related to
latrine usage, drinking and cooking water sources, and water
storage practices. Environmental samples (soil, sand, drain
sediment, drain water, flood sediment, and flood water) were
collected, and analyzed for E. coli. Analysis of variance
(ANOVA) procedures or chi-squared and Fisher's tests were used to
compare household characteristics and practices by neighborhood.
After analyzing the distributions of E. coli concentration
for each type of environmental sample through ANOVAs and kernel
density distributions, a weighted fecal contamination score was
created, stratifying by both sample type and neighborhood, to
compare E. coli concentrations.
Results: Study neighborhoods differed significantly in most
demographic, infrastructure, sanitation- and hygiene-specific
characteristics. E. coli levels were the highest in drain
water samples (mean:8.56 log10CFUs), followed by floodwater samples
(mean:6.77 log10CFUs), but significant heterogeneity was only
observed in sediment samples from flood areas. Shiabu had the
greatest proportion of environmental samples with E. coli
categorization, and the highest E. coli concentrations.
Discussion: Differences in neighborhood socioeconomic and
structural characteristics were associated with differences in
fecal contamination in the urban environment. There was significant
heterogeneity in neighborhood-specific access to improved
sanitation. Neighborhoods more likely to experience flooding events
had higher fecal contamination levels in flood-related samples;
otherwise, drain samples had the highest fecal contamination
levels. Only sediment samples from flood areas had average E.
coli concentrations that were significantly different between
neighborhoods. Fecal contamination in the public domain may pose a
serious health risk to low-income urban populations. The
relationship between urban drainage, flooding, and fecal
contamination in low-income neighborhoods should be further
investigated.

Title: Role of TMS1/ASC in Breast Epithelial Anoikis and Migration
Abstract:
Cellular detachment from the extracellular matrix (ECM) induces
a form of apoptosis, referred to as "anoikis." Most cancer cells
are resistant to anoikis and survive independently of ECM
interactions. Previously, we identified a pro-apoptotic gene,
TMS1 that is epigenetically silenced in breast cancers.
Overexpression of TMS1 is sufficient to induce procaspase-8
cleavage in breast cells in the absence of death receptor-ligand
interactions. Additionally, TMS1 aggregates to form ‘specks'
in some apoptotic cells, although the function of this structure
remains unclear. Here we established a role for TMS1 in anoikis and
uncovered a nonapoptotic role for TMS1 in cell migration. We show
that cellular detachment induces TMS1 expression. In addition, we
find that silencing TMS1 confers resistance to anoikis through a
delay in procaspase-8 cleavage and accumulation of BimEL. ERK1/2
signaling negatively regulates BimEL accumulation during
detachment. We found that silencing TMS1 resulted in persistent
ERK1/2 signaling during anoikis. We conclude that loss of TMS1
promotes resistance to anoikis in part through misregulation of
ERK1/2 signaling and suppression of BimEL accumulation. During the
course of these studies a nonapoptotic role for procaspase-8 in
cell adhesion and migration was elucidated by many groups. The next
phase of our research was aimed towards deciphering a role for TMS1
upstream of procaspase-8 in anoikis. Thus, we next investigated a
nonapoptotic role for TMS1 in these processes. We found that
adhesion to fibronectin induced the redistribution of TMS1 to
barrel-like structures. Silencing TMS1 delayed FAK and
ERK1/2 signaling in response to integrin-fibronectin interactions.
Phosphorylated FAK and centrosomal markers colocalized with TMS1 at
barrel-like structures in a subset of cells. Through functional
analyses, we further demonstrated a role for TMS1 in cell
migration. These data suggest that an association of TMS1 with
centrosomes results in the formation of a critical signaling center
that may regulate migration. In conclusion, our data demonstrate
distinct functions for TMS1 in anoikis and migration. Overall,
results from these studies have increased our understanding of the
intricate functions TMS1 exhibits in epithelial cells and has
provided great insight into the consequences of aberrant
methylation and silencing of TMS1 observed in many cancers.

Title:
Approval Sheet Risk Factors for Poor Treatment Outcomes
among Patients with Multi-Drug Resistant and Extensively
Drug-Resistant (M/XDR) Tuberculosis in the Country of Georgia.
Abstract:
Abstract
Introduction:
Resistance of M. tuberculosis to anti-tuberculosis drugs
has become a
major public health problem in many countries, including Georgia.
In 2008, Georgian
National Tuberculosis Program introduced treatment with second line
anti-tuberculosis
drugs, which has allowed for treatment of multidrug or extensively
drug-resistant
tuberculosis (M/XDR)-TB. The study objectives were to assess
treatment outcomes
among the 1st cohort of patients with pulmonary M/XDR-TB and to
determine risk factors
for poor treatment outcomes: defined as death, failure and
default.
Methods: A prospective observational cohort study was
performed. All patients with
M/XDR pulmonary TB who initiated treatment in 2008 were enrolled
and followed until
2010. Descriptive statistics were used to determine associations
between study
covariates. Binary logistic regression analysis was utilized to
determine independent
association of prior treatment history with treatment outcome while
controlling for
potential confounding variables.
Results: 380 patients were included: male (71%); mean age 38
years; median age 38.4
years. 13% had XDR-TB. 1.3% had HIV co-infection. Body Mass Index
(BMI) was <18.5
among 24% of the cohort, and 52% had bilateral lesions on chest
X-ray. Surgery was
performed in 10% (37) of cases. The treatment outcomes were as
follows: 47% had a
poor outcome (death among 59 patients [15%], failure among 37
[10%], and 83 [22%] -
defaulted). In the final multivariable analysis, history of
previous treatment (OR=2.8 95%
CI 1.2 - 6.3) was significantly associated with poor treatment
after controlling for risk
factors. Other independent variables associated with poor treatment
outcomes included
absence of adjunctive surgical therapy (OR 3.7, 95%CI 1.5, 8.7), no
sputum culture
conversion to negative by 4 months (OR 3.0, 95%CI 1.9, 5.0), the
presence of XDR-TB
(OR 2.3, 95% CI 1.2, 2.4), BMI < 18.5 (OR 2.0, 95%CI 1.1, 3.4)
and bilateral lesions on
chest radiograph (OR 1.8, 95%CI 1.2, 2.9).
Conclusions: Overall, 47% of patients with M/XDR-TB had poor
treatment outcome. In
multivariable analysis, independent risk factors for a poor
treatment outcome included
prior TB treatment history, lack of adjunctive surgical
intervention, no culture conversion
by month 4, XDR-TB, low BMI (<18.5) and bilateral lesions on
chest X-ray.

Cover Page

Risk Factors for Poor Treatment Outcomes among Patients with
Multi-Drug
Resistant and Extensively Drug-Resistant (M/XDR) Tuberculosis in
Georgia.
By
Medea Gegia, MD
Advisor: Henry M. Blumberg, MD
Advisor: John Boring, Ph.D
Advisor: Thomas Ziegler, M.D
A thesis submitted to the Faculty of the
James T. Laney Graduate Studies of Emory University
in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of
Master of Science
in Clinical Research
2011

Title: Role of TMS1/ASC in Breast Epithelial Anoikis and Migration
Abstract:
Cellular detachment from the extracellular matrix (ECM) induces
a form of
apoptosis, referred to as "anoikis." Most cancer cells are
resistant to anoikis and survive
independently of ECM interactions. Previously, we identified a
pro-apoptotic gene,
TMS1 that is epigenetically silenced in breast cancers.
Overexpression of TMS1 is
sufficient to induce procaspase-8 cleavage in breast cells in the
absence of death receptor-
ligand interactions. Additionally, TMS1 aggregates to form 'specks'
in some apoptotic
cells, although the function of this structure remains unclear.
Here we established a role
for TMS1 in anoikis and uncovered a nonapoptotic role for TMS1 in
cell migration. We
show that cellular detachment induces TMS1 expression. In addition,
we find that
silencing TMS1 confers resistance to anoikis through a delay in
procaspase-8 cleavage
and accumulation of BimEL. ERK1/2 signaling negatively regulates
BimEL
accumulation during detachment. We found that silencing TMS1
resulted in persistent
ERK1/2 signaling during anoikis. We conclude that loss of TMS1
promotes resistance to
anoikis in part through misregulation of ERK1/2 signaling and
suppression of BimEL
accumulation. During the course of these studies a nonapoptotic
role for procaspase-8 in
adhesion and migration was elucidated by many groups. The next
phase of our research
was aimed towards deciphering a role for TMS1 upstream of
procaspase-8 in anoikis.
Thus, we next investigated a nonapoptotic role for TMS1 in these
processes. We found
that adhesion to fibronectin induced the redistribution of TMS1 to
barrel-like structures.
Silencing TMS1 delayed FAK and ERK1/2 signaling in response to
integrin-fibronectin
interactions. Phosphorylated FAK and centrosomal markers
colocalized with TMS1 at
barrel-like structures in a subset of cells. Through functional
analyses, we further
demonstrated a role for TMS1 in cell migration. These data
suggest that an association of
TMS1 with centrosomes results in the formation of a critical
signaling center that may
regulate migration. In conclusion, our data demonstrate distinct
functions for TMS1 in
anoikis and migration. Overall, results from these studies have
increased our
understanding of the intricate functions TMS1 exhibits in
epithelial cells and has
provided great insight into the consequences of aberrant
methylation and silencing of
TMS1 observed in many cancers.

Title:
Consuming News as a Millennial: Undergraduates' News Consumption
Practices and Their Effects on Identity Formation and Civic
Engagement
Abstract:
Abstract
Consuming News as a Millennial: Undergraduates' News Consumption
Practices and Their
Effects on Identity Formation and Civic Engagement

This study aims to present the news consumption and civic
engagement habits of a select group
of undergraduate students at a major research university. By
building upon the research methods and
frameworks used by Dr. Debra Spitulnik Vidali (2006-present), the
present research aims to reveal how
undergraduate students think about and use news material in their
daily lives to form individual
identities and develop connections among social groups and
democratic institutions. Individuals' habits
and perceptions with respect to news consumption and civic
engagement were revealed through
facilitated smal group interviews and written surveys.
This paper argues that undergraduates' news consumption and civic
engagement habits are
highly personalized and largely shaped by peer influence. Students
who currently read, watch, or listen
to the news on a regular basis feel that news consumption is an
imperative habit in order to successful y
participate in classroom discussions and conversations with others
and contribute to the functioning of
the nation itself. Most students who do not consume news regularly
believe that they should be more
knowledgeable about current events in order to participate ful y in
democratic processes, but cite a lack
of time and personal relevance as reasons why they do not actively
seek this knowledge. As a result, I
argue that undergraduates' media ideologies and idioms of practice
surrounding news media outlets,
and particularly Internet--based outlets, are informing further
personalization of news and civic
engagement. While current preferences toward personalized news
consumption and civic engagement
are both constructive and valid, they cannot replace the knowledge
of informed citizenship that
promotes the overal health of a democratic country. In order for
democracy to survive in the hands of
the millennials, I argue that news must be considered relevant and
important in the context of everyday
lives of these individuals.

Title:
Time and Space, Truth and Fiction in the Works of H. G. Wells and
Henry James
Abstract:
A number of scientific and technological innovations that came
about during the
nineteenth century had a resounding effect on Victorian culture.
The advent of the
railway along with the introduction of new communications media and
radical biological
and geological discoveries had major implications for western
society's understanding of
the relationship between space and time and of humanity's role
within that relationship.
As time and space were expanded, the speed at which they could be
experienced caused
them to be simultaneously annihilated, greatly increasing the
number of impressions -
and the amount of experience - an individual could acquire. By the
1890s, the effects of
this phenomenon had become some of the most widely discussed topics
in a multitude of
cultural discourses, and since, as H. Porter Abbott writes in the
Cambridge Introduction
to Narrative, "the representation of conflict in narrative
provides a way for a culture to
talk to itself about, and possibly resolve, conflicts that threaten
to fracture it (or at least
making living difficult)," the literature produced during the last
decade of the century
exemplifies the extent to which these changes influenced society on
both individual and
collective levels.1 This thesis focuses on two works by Henry James
- The Turn of the
Screw and In the Cage, both published in 1898 - as well
as H. G. Wells's The Time
Machine, published in 1895. Shortly after these works were
introduced into Victorian
culture, James and Wells became involved in a lifelong quarrel
regarding the purpose of
the novel: Wells adeptly explained it in a 1915 letter to James
when he stated, "to you
literature like painting is an end, to me literature like
architecture is a means, it has a
use."2 Despite their differences - as Wells confessed, "I had a
queer feeling that we were
both incompatibly right" - both authors address the newly-realized
ambiguity of the
relationships between time and space, truth and fiction, man and
machine.3

Title: Chains of Love in Law; Revisiting Plural Marriage
Abstract:
This dissertation explores an area at the intersection of
family law, religious liberty and criminal law: the issue of plural
marriage. As American keeps moving in the direction of favoring
consensual adult relationships regardless of their nature, polygamy
has been slowly making a comeback in the national consciousness.
Arguments include First, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights to
religious liberty, due process, and equality. The first part of
this dissertation explores the issue of legalizing plural marriage
from a legislative and administrative standpoint, while the second
part argues that, regardless of whether or not the technicalities
can be worked out on paper, from a public policy perspective,
polygamy is a poor choice. It argues from experience, with detailed
reference to the Jewish legal system's dramatic move away from the
practice of plural marriage.

Title:
Determinants of Uncontrolled Blood Pressure among African Americans
using Electronic Medical Records, 2008-2011.
Abstract:
Abstract
Determinants of Uncontrolled Blood Pressure among African
Americans using Electronic Medical Records, 2008-2011
By Yi-Ting Chou
Hypertension is a common chronic disease affecting more than 75
million adults in the United States. Particularly in African
Americans, hypertension is more common, more severe, develops at an
earlier age, and leads to more clinical sequelae. Moreover,
Hypertension control rates in the United States remain lower in
African Americans compared to Caucasians. Nevertheless, potential
risk factors of uncontrolled hypertension have not been
sufficiently investigated in clinical population.
To understand the multidimensional determinants of uncontrolled
blood pressure in African Americans, we used an electronic medical
record system in Georgia and identified a sample of 3,135 newly
treated hypertensive African Americans aged ≥20. The primary
outcomes of interest were 1) Blood pressure (BP) controlled or not
after treatment, and 2) the quantitative changes in SBP and DBP
before and after treatment. Potential risk factors examined
included age, sex, BMI, Socioeconomic status socioeconomic status,
medication adherence, the use of diuretics or calcium channel
blockers, comorbidities. The associations of risk factors with
blood pressure and uncontrolled hypertension were examined by
linear and logistic regression models, respectively.
Under the unadjusted model, medication adherence (medication
possession ratio ≥0.8) was significantly associated with BP
control with a reduction of 5.4 and 3.3 mmHg compared to
non-adherent patient in SBP and DBP respectively. The use of
diuretics was associated with a reduction in SBP while the use of
CCB was observed with association in both SBP and DBP response.
Diabetes (DM), stroke, chronic kidney disease (CKD), and end stage
renal disease (ESRD) were associated with SBP increases even after
treatment. Controlling for age, sex, BMI, and medication adherence,
diuretics was still significantly associated with a SBP reduction
but not DBP. DM was associated with DBP reduction, while CKD or
ESRD was associated with increases in SBP, respectively. Low SES is
associated with less reduction of SBP and DBP among treated African
Americans.
We concluded that adherence to antihypertensive medication, the
comorbidity, and the category of antihypertensive medication
strongly influenced BP response among African Americans.

Title:
Determining the effects of animal migration and range expansion on
population genetics and genomics

Analyzing Multicellular Interactions: A hybrid Computational and
Biological Pattern Recognition Approach
Abstract:
Pluripotent embryonic stem cells (ESCs) can differentiate into
all somatic cell types, making them a useful platform for studying
a variety of cellular phenomenon. Furthermore, ESCs can be induced
to form aggregates called embryoid bodies (EBs) which recapitulate
the dynamics of development and morphogenesis. However, many
different factors such as gradients of soluble morphogens, direct
cell-to-cell signaling, and cell-matrix interactions have all been
implicated in directing ESC differentiation. Though the effects of
individual factors have often been investigated independently, the
inherent difficulty in assaying combinatorial effects has made it
difficult to ascertain the concerted effects of different
environmental parameters, particularly due to the spatial and
temporal dynamics associated with such cues. Dynamic computational
models of ESC differentiation can provide powerful insight into how
different cues function in combination both spatially and
temporally. By combining particle based diffusion models, cellular
agent based approaches, and physical models of morphogenesis, a
multi-scale, rules-based modeling framework can provide insight
into how each component contributes to differentiation. I propose
to investigate the complex regulatory cues which govern complex
morphogenic behavior in 3D ESC systems via a computational rules
based modeling approach. The objective of this study is to examine
how spatial patterns of differentiation by ESCs arise as a function
of the microenvironment. The central hypothesis is that spatial
control of soluble morphogens and cell-cell signaling will allow
enhanced control over the patterns and efficiency of stem cell
differentiation in embryoid bodies.

Title:
Moral Permissibility of Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO):
Casuist Moral Reasoning

The Identification and Mapping of a Gene Responsible for a Novel
nonEmo Phenotype in C. elegans Oocytes
Abstract:
I am currently investigating a novel oocyte phenotype in
the nematode C. elegans. Unlike human oocytes, which remain
meiotically arrested unless fertilized, ovulated C. elegans
oocytes undergo continuous endomitotic DNA replication and
consequentially become polyploid when left unfertilized. Wild type
(WT) worms therefore, are said to have an "Emo"
(endomitotic oocyte)
phenotype. A novel "nonEmo" phenotype was discovered when a strain
that contained him-8(e1462) was found to produce
ovulated oocytes that remained arrested in meiotic prophase I when
left unfertilized. Because oocyte meiotic arrest would greatly aid
in the process of realizing an in vitro fertilization (IVF)
model in C. elegans, understanding the genetic basis of this
strain's nonEmo phenotype is important, as it has the potential to
produce oocytes of a quantity and quality suitable for IVF in C.
elegans. C. elegans fertilization in vivo is
difficult to observe, as it is tightly coupled to ovulation and
occurs rapidly in a chamber (the spermatheca) filled with sperm
that block the view of the oocyte. IVF is desired, as it would
allow for an unobstructed view of sperm-oocyte interactions prior
to fertilization and control of variables such as the location,
time, and environment of sperm-egg binding. IVF would also allow
detailed spatial and temporal analyses of sperm mutants that
exhibit defects during fertilization. I have used PCR, DNA
sequencing, RNAi technology, and conventional genetics to show that
loss-of-function mutations in the gene C10C5.1 are
responsible for the nonEmo phenotype. This gene encodes a Piezo
protein, which is postulated to function as a mechanosensitive ion
channel. My work has taken a strain that harbored multiple
mutations and clearly shown that the nonEmo phenotype results from
loss-of-function for one gene. Future work will focus
on determining the tissue in which lack of C10C5.1 expression
causes the nonEmo phenotype. Along with investigating how the
nonEmo phenotype is regulated, further work will need to be
performed to determine if C10C5.1 mutants are in fact suitable
oocyte donors for IVF.

elegans: Reproductive Anatomy, Gametogenesis, and Fertilization (1)

elegans (3) -- C. In vitro Fertilization (IVF) (5) -- D. Discovery
of a C. elegans Mutant that Could Act as a Potential Oocyte Donor
for IVF (8) -- Chapter 2: Initial Characterization of the Genetic
Region Containing the nonEmo Mutation (10) -- Chapter 3: Genetic
Analyses of the nonEmo Region on Chromosome IV -- A. Introduction

Title:
Secondary Eating and Obesity in a Nationally Representative
Population
Abstract:
Introduction: Obesity has become one of the United States' most
pressing public health issues. Almost 35% of Americans are obese
according to most recent prevalence data. Research on eating
behaviors has shown that eating while distracted can cause people
to consume more than they realize, with small changes in awareness
leading to lowered ability to self-regulate food consumption. Most
research on distracted eating has been conducted in controlled
settings. However, observing overall behavioral trends in
free-living adults can garner insight into the effect that
secondary eating, or eating while engaged in other activities, has
on body composition. This analysis assesses the relationship
between time spent engaged in secondary eating and obesity.

Methods: Data for this analysis on 11,369 adult respondents were
taken from the 2008 American Time Use Survey, a cross-sectional
survey conducted to obtain nationally representative estimates on
how Americans spend their time. In 2008, the supplemental Eating
and Health Module was conducted to obtain information directly
related to food and eating behaviors. Three logistic regression
models were run to observe the association between BMI and
secondary eating: one unadjusted, one adjusting for selected
demographic characteristics, and one adjusting for selected
demographic characteristics and selected time use variables.
Results: The sample used in this analysis had a mean BMI of 27.4
and a median BMI of 26.6. 53% of all respondents engaged in
secondary eating during the day. Non-obese respondents spent on
average 0.53 hours engaged in secondary eating per day, while obese
respondents spent on average 0.38 hours. In all three models, those
who spent more than 30 minutes engaged in secondary eating had
lower odds of being obese (OR = 0.77, 95% CI: 0.64-0.95) compared
to those who did not engage in secondary eating at all.

Discussion: This analysis observed lower odds of obesity in those
who spent longer engaged in secondary eating. This relationship
could have been influenced by the volume and types of food
typically consumed during secondary eating occasions. Future
research focused on capturing differences in types of food consumed
during secondary eating is necessary to further explore this
behavior.

Title: Drinking from the
Abstract:
Abstract
Drinking from the Byzantine Tradition: John Wesley's Synthetic
Understanding of
Anthropology, Soteriology, and Teleology.
By Robert Steven Reneau
During his life and the centuries after his death, many scholars
see the theology of
John Wesley as attempting to bridge a gap between Roman Catholicism
and
Protestantism. However, since Albert C. Outler mentioned in a
footnote of the bottom his
book titled John Wesley in 1964 that Wesley also pulled from
the early Byzantine
tradition, scholars are now attempting to place Wesley's work in a
new light that attempts
to bridge the paradigms of the Western church and Eastern church.
This work shows how
Wesley forged a synthetic understanding of anthroplogy,
soteriology, and teleology that
is heavily based in Western notions, but also drawing from multiple
early Greek voices
like Clement of Alexandrius, Macarius/Gregory of Nyssa, and
Chrysostom.

Drinking from the Byzantine Tradition: John Wesley's Synthetic
Understanding of
Anthropology, Soteriology, and Teleology.
By
Robert Steven Reneau
B.A., Birmingham-Southern College, 2004
Thesis Committee Chair: Dr. Steven J. Kraftchick
A thesis submitted to the Faculty of the
Candler School of Theology
in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of
Masters of Divinity
2011

Title:
Immunological determinants of viremia during pathogenic and
non-pathogenic SIV infection
Abstract:
After more than twenty-five years of strenuous research, an
effective AIDS vaccine to prevent
HIV infection has yet to be developed. This is largely due to a
lack of understanding of how HIV
interacts with the human immune system and causes pathogenesis. The
goal of my thesis was to
better understand determinants of viremia during HIV pathogenesis
by utilizing non-human
primate models. Natural SIV infection of sooty mangabeys (SMs)
provides a non-pathogenic
model of HIV, since despite high levels of viremia, these animals
maintain peripheral CD4+ T
cells and do not progress to AIDS. Pathogenic SIV infection of
rhesus macaques (RMs),
however, is a widely used model for HIV in humans since these
animals have high viremia,
depletion of peripheral CD4+ T cells, and eventual progression to
AIDS. In the first aim of my
thesis, I assessed the determinants of set-point viremia in
naturally SIV-infected SMs, i.e.,
immune control versus target cell limitation. To address this
issue, I depleted CD4+ T cells in
naturally SIV-infected SMs, and found that set-point viremia is
determined by the availability of
activated CD4+ T cells, but not measures of immune control. In the
second aim of my thesis, I
sought to better understand the role of CD8+ T cells during
pathogenic SIV infection of RMs by
determining the lifespan of SIV-infected cells in vivo
either in the presence (control) or absence
(CD8+ lymphocyte-depleted) of CD8+ T cells. I found that depletion
of CD8+ lymphocytes did
not result in an increased lifespan of productively infected cells
in vivo, which indicates that
direct killing of cells producing virus is unlikely to be a major
mechanism underlying the anti-
viral effect of CD8+ T cells during SIV infection. Taken together,
the results of my thesis studies
have important implications for the development of AIDS vaccines
and therapies. These studies
provide a significant improvement in our understanding of the
complex interactions between HIV
and the immune system, and will hopefully lead to a re-analysis of
current HIV vaccination
strategies in order to produce more efficacious vaccines with
appropriate targets.

Title:
The Role of Rap1 Signaling during Prostate Cancer Progression and
the PI3K/Akt Pathway as its Potential Regulator
Abstract:
Abstract
The Role of Rap1 Signaling during Prostate Cancer
Progression
and its Potential Regulator, the PI3K/Akt Pathway
By Veronica Mwihaki Henderson
Rap1 is a small G-protein implicated in the regulation of
E-cadherin cell-cell junctions
and integrin-mediated cell-matrix adhesions. Our expression
profiling of clinical prostate
cancer tissue samples showed significantly decreased Rap1A mRNA
levels in tumor
compared to normal tissue samples, while a negative regulator of
Rap1, Rap1GAP, was
significantly increased. Furthermore, these changes in Rap1A and
Rap1GAP expression
were significantly correlated with Gleason tumor grade, suggesting
that reduced Rap1
signals play a role in metastatic progression. Tissue microarray
analysis confirmed this
correlation at the protein level for Rap1GAP. Furthermore, siRNA
knockdown of Rap1A
and Rap1B resulted in increased LNCaP cell migration as measured in
a wound healing
assay. Stable expression of the PTEN tumor suppressor in C4-2
prostate cancer cells
resulted in changes in cell morphology as well as increased Rap1
protein levels,
suggesting that the PI3K/AKT pathway may regulate Rap1 expression.
Treatment of
prostate cancer cells with an inhibitor of PI3K increased mRNA
expression of the Rap1A
and Rap1B genes, supporting this hypothesis. Thus, activation of
the PI3K/AKT pathway
may be one mechanism by which Rap1 expression is repressed during
prostate cancer
progression, resulting in enhanced cell migration.

The Role of Rap1 Signaling during Prostate Cancer
Progression
and its Potential Regulator, the PI3K/Akt Pathway
By
Veronica Mwihaki Henderson
B.S., Clark Atlanta University, 2000
Advisor: Carlos S. Moreno, Ph.D.
A thesis submitted to the Faculty of the
James T. Laney School of Graduate Studies of Emory University
in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of
Master of Science in
Graduate Division of Biological and Biomedical Science
Genetics and Molecular Biology
2010

Title:
HIV Prevention in Transnational Communities: Developing a Model
of Trust and Social Influence among Immigrant Latinos in North
Carolina
Abstract:
Early detection of HIV-positive status and entry into
treatment is the most efficacious way to prevent the spread and/or
progression of the disease. However surveillance data and cohort
studies indicate Latinos in the United States (U.S.) are more
likely than non-Latino blacks and whites to delay testing, present
to care with an AIDS defining illness, and die within one year of
learning their HIV-positive status. Recent studies have shown that
U.S. immigrants from Mexico and Central America are more likely to
delay testing and treatment compared to other foreign-born groups;
and Latinos in southeastern settlement states may delay seeking
care longer than Latinos in more established immigrant
destinations. Because time lived in the U.S. and acculturation are
often associated with increased behavioral risk and suboptimal
health outcomes among Latinos, it is important to understand how
combinations of sociopolitical and acculturative influences in new
settlement areas may affect personal health assessments,
socio-medical intuitions, and likelihood of
HIV-testing/treatment-adherence over time.
This research develops emerging theories linking
socio-acculturative factors and endorsements of trust in medical
care to HIV-prevention and public health criteria. The research
uses data collected in 2008-2009 from three NIH and extramurally
funded studies to address three specific aims: (1) Assess validity
of the adapted Wake Forest University Medical Trust Scale
among Spanish-speaking men and women from Mexico and Central
America; (2) Estimate structural relationships between
socio-acculturative influences, self-rated health status, and
HIV-testing, adjusting for length of residence in the U.S.; and (3)
Examine how legal stress and medical trust modulate effects of the
HoMBReS HIV prevention intervention. This research advances
theory and measurement of psychological processes in the most
rapidly growing U.S. populations experiencing the most severe
AIDS-related outcomes.

Title:
Addressing the Sexual Health of the Homeless: Recommendations for
STI Prevention Education for Homeless Women

Treatment of diabetic neuropathy in a
streptozotocin-induced diabetic rat model with bone marrow-derived
mesenchymal stem cells
Abstract:
Recent evidence has suggested that diabetic neuropathy
(DN) is pathophysiologically related to both impaired angiogenesis
and a deficiency of neurotrophic factors in the nerves. It is
widely known that vascular and neural growth are intimately
associated. Mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) promote angiogenesis in
ischemic diseases and have neuroprotective effects, particularly on
Schwann cells. Accordingly, we investigated whether DN could be
improved by local transplantation of MSCs by augmenting
angiogenesis and neural regeneration such as remyelination. In
sciatic nerves of streptozotocin (STZ)-induced diabetic rats, motor
and sensory nerve conduction velocities (NCVs) and capillary
density were reduced, and axonal atrophy and demyelination were
observed. After injection of bone marrow-derived MSCs (BM-MSCs)
into hindlimb muscles, NCVs were restored to near-normal levels.
Histological examination demonstrated that injected MSCs were
preferentially and durably engrafted in the sciatic nerves, and a
portion of the engrafted MSCs were distinctively localized close to
vasa nervora of sciatic nerves. Furthermore, vasa nervora increased
in density, and ultrastructure of myelinated fibers in nerves were
observed to be restored. Real-time RT-PCR experiments showed that
gene expression of multiple factors involved in angiogenesis,
neural function, and myelination were increased in the MSC-injected
nerves. These findings suggest that MSC transplantation improved DN
through direct peripheral nerve angiogenesis, neurotrophic effects,
and restoration of myelination.

Title:
MEXICO, INTERRUPTED: THE IDEA OF WORK IN MEXICAN CULTURAL
PRODUCTION, 1857-1952
Abstract:
This dissertation argues that for more than a century and
a half, the Mexican intelligentsia approached the question of work
and its opposites in its attempts to explain the seeming
contradiction of a Mexico that was materially rich yet which
languished in underdevelopment. To this end, I trace
the constitution of what I call the Mexican "archive of work"
through key moments in the nation's cultural history in which
attempts were made to articulate a work ethic capable of delivering
the nation into prosperity, while at the same time remaining
authentically Mexican. I define the "archive of work" as a
discursive matrix composed of three conceptual nuclei--the
Christian notion of duty, the liberal notion of work as
self-development, and the thermodynamic and scientistic notion of
metabolic work--which determines all discussions of work and its
opposites in modern Mexico. My chapters engage a wide array of
written cultural objects that spans a variety of genres: from the
assorted writings, legislations, articles, speeches and novels of
19th century liberal and conservative lettered elite, to
the textual production--philosophical treatises, essays, and
novels--of the mid twentieth century. Together, these documents
allow for an exploration of the idea of work in Mexico and the
ontological and political narratives about man's place in the world
that serve as its ground.

Title:
James in the "Q" Sayings Tradition: An Examination of the Jesus
Logia in the Epistle of St. James
Abstract:
ABSTRACT
James in the "Q" Sayings Tradition: An Examination of the
Jesus Logia in the Epistle of St. James
The present investigation concerns itself with assessing the
relationship between the Epistle of
James and the sayings traditions of Jesus, as found in the
Synoptics. For most observers, the use of Jesus
logia
reasonable doubt. Nevertheless, the nature and
extent of the affinities between James and the Gospels remain a
matter of debate among scholars. The
questions raised
revolve around debates over which
passages in James are identifiable as derivative of a Jesus
logion. Secondarily, the extent to which James
utilizes such traditions has been recognized as a possible window
into the Sitz im Leben of the Jamesian
community (itself a notoriously difficult question).
The thesis which guides the present discussion can be stated as
follows: the Epistle of James
represents an early stage in the development of the Jesus tradition
found in the Synoptic Gospels.
Correspondingly, it reflects a pre-gospel stage of development in
the sayings of Jesus, reminiscent of the
form found in the Q source (particularly in its Matthean
recension). The two test cases for this hypothesis
will be Jas 2:5 and Jas 5:12. The reason for the selection of these
passages in particular is that they are
nearly universally accepted
of the words of Jesus. Before undertaking
an exegesis of these passages it will be necessary to briefly
review the relevant literature, in order to see
how Jamesian scholarship has developed from its origins to its
current state. Following the exegesis of the
targeted verses in James, we will conclude our investigation with a
summary of our findings and an
assessment of their implications.

James in the "Q" Sayings Tradition
An examination of the Jesus Logia in the Epistle of St.
James
B.A., University of Illinois Springfield, 2010
Thesis Committee Chair: Luke Timothy Johnson, PhD.
A thesis submitted to the Faculty of the
Candler School of Theology
In partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of
Masters of Theological Studies
May 2012

Title: Enhancements of Cellular Therapy for Ischemic Stroke
Abstract:
Ischemic stroke is a leading cause of death and disability
in the United States. Treatment options are currently limited, and
currently only one FDA-approved therapy exists (tPA). Although tPA
was a great stride forward in stroke treatment, only a small
percentage of patients are eligible to receive the drug and even
smaller actually receive it. Research to date has focused on small
molecule and peptide based therapies aimed at neuroprotection:
protecting dying neurons, glia, and vascular from ischemia-media
cell death. Decades of pre-clinical studies generated exciting
results in animal models, however all have failed to translate to
successful patient care. Currently, there are no therapies
available to promote central nervous system (CNS recovery) in
stroke survivors. Cellular therapy, the use of stem cells for
stroke treatment, has blossomed in the lab in the past decade.
Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPS cells, or iPSCs) in particular
are an excellent candidate for future stroke therapies. With
multiple mechanisms of action and the possibility for not only
neuronal cell replacement but personalized medicine as well, the
use of iPSCs for stroke therapy holds great potential. Current
studies generate as proof-of-principal that iPSC transplantation
can be safe, efficacious, and can provide a source of new neurons
that integrate into host circuitry. While these studies are
exciting, they are far from ideal. Many questions remain and in its
current form, iPSC transplantation for stroke is not optimized and
remains inefficient. This dissertation examines how iPSC
transplantation may be optimized for ischemic stroke treatment. We
examined a novel intranasal transplantation route as well as a
novel genetic manipulation method (focal adhesion kinase, FAK,
overexpression we hypothesized would improve functional recovery
over current methods. Our results suggest that the novel
non-invasive intranasal transplantation may improve functional
recovery at a similar level compared to existing methods. We also
demonstrate FAK overexpression may improve some aspects of normal
neuronal development that would aid the integration of
transplantated cells. Taken together, our data suggest that
optimization of existing iPSC transplantation methods may benefit
iPSC therapy for ischemic stroke.
Table of Contents:
CHAPTER 1 - ISCHEMIC STROKE 1 -- INTRODUCTION 2 -- ISCHEMIC STROKE

Title:
Paul on the Road to Natchez: Resurrection and Conversion in the
Christ-Haunted South
Abstract:
Abstract
Paul on the Road to Natchez: Conversion and Resurrection in the
Christ-Haunted South
By Mary Elizabeth Button
Paul on the Road to Natchez is a project that is comprised
of both paintings and essays in
which the conversion of Paul is imagined at various sites along the
Natchez Trace. In
each of the fifteen pieces in the series, well-know images of
Saul's conversion (some
from art history, others from family Bibles) have been reproduced
within an illustration
of sites along the Natchez Trace. Saul's journey to Damascus, and
the blinding light of
the resurrected Christ that transforms Saul into Paul, provides the
narrative structure for
the project.

Paul on the Road to Natchez: Conversion and Resurrection in the
Christ-Haunted South
By
Mary Elizabeth Button
Bachelor of Fine Arts
New York University
2006
Thesis Committee Chair: Rev. Barbara Day Miller, M.Div
A thesis submitted to the Faculty of the
Candler School of Theology
in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of
Master of Theological Studies
2011

Title: Major and Minor Alloimmunization Induced
Abstract:
Major and Minor Alloimmunization Induced by Platelet
Transfusions:
Mechanisms, Consequences, and Interventions

By
Seema Rajnikant Patel
In response to vasculature injury, anucleated cell fragments,
referred to as platelets,
adhere and aggregate to damaged blood vessels to preserve
hemostasis through clot
formation and wound healing. Platelet disorders resulting in low
platelet counts or
dysfunctional platelets can require aggressive platelet transfusion
support to aid in
maintaining proper hemostasis levels. Although a vital therapy,
platelet transfusions are
associated with long-term clinical consequences, such as
development of donor specific
alloimmunity and consequential refractoriness to subsequent
platelet transfusions.
When successful, bone marrow transplantations are a potential cure
for the above
patients. In a non-malignant setting, eligible patients can receive
Human Leukocyte
Antigen (HLA)-matched bone marrow transplant. Due to the absence of
neoplasia in
such patients, it is difficult to justify the toxic effects of
stringent conditioning regimens
that are otherwise beneficial in eradicating cancerous cells and
promoting engraftment.
Thus, many physicians choose to transplant under reduced intensity
conditions.
However, under these conditions, it is observed that chronically
transfused patients
reject the HLA-matched bone marrow transplant at higher rates than
minimally or un-
transfused patients. Because the transplants are HLA-matched or
-identical, it is
predicted that rejection is due to minor histocompatibility
antigens. Therefore, the goal
of the current dissertation is to test and characterize the role of
prior alloimmunization
against minor histocompatibility antigens, expressed by transfused
platelet units, in the
rejection of an MHC-identical, unrelated donor bone marrow
transplant. The data
presented herein demonstrate that minor histocompatibility
antigen reactive cellular
alloimmunity induced in response to allogeneic leukocyte reduced
platelet transfusions
can induce rejection of a subsequent MHC-matched bone marrow
transplant expressing
the target minor histocompatibility antigens under reduced
intensity conditions. To the
extent that the observed murine biology reflects human physiology,
these findings
additionally indicate potential clinical interventions to overcome
refractoriness to platelet
or red blood cell transfusions and rejection of an HLA-matched
transplant under
reduced intensity conditions in allogeneic platelet transfused
patients.

Approval Sheet "Trouble in Paradise: Disharmony among Magisterial
Interpretations of the Adamic Narrative"
Abstract:
I propose a thesis that whereas the Second Vatican
Council and the Catechism of the Catholic Church endorse the
application of the historical-critical method to scripture, the
catechism's historicist interpretation of the Adamic stands in
tension with the broad consensus of current scholarship, and
underscores the necessity of a hermeneutics of suspicion in the
interpretation of magisterial formulations. I trace relations
between the magisterium and modern biblical scholarship, noting the
magisterium‘s endorsement of the historical-critical method
in Divino Afflante Spiritu (1943), a statement by the
Pontifical Biblical Commission in the Enchiridion Biblicum
(1954), Dei Verbum (1965), and the 1992 Catechism of the
Catholic Church # 109-112. I then assert the compatibility of
the historical-critical method with canonical exegesis, proposing
that the application of the historical-critical method can be
highly compatible with fidelity to the faith tradition. Next, I
take the Adamic myth as a case-study so as to compare, on the one
hand, the broad consensus of contemporary exegetes it in light of
the historical-critical method and, on the other, the manner in
which the 1992 catechism interprets the text. I propose that the
broad consensus of contemporary exegetes regards the Adamic
narrative as myth, fall account, etiology, and polemic but not as
the recollection, figurative or otherwise, of a particular
historical event. I note that Vatican Two‘s Gaudium et
Spes (1965) evokes the myth in a manner consistent with this
scholarly consensus, utilizing the term "beginning", with reference
to God rather than a historical beginning. In contrast, the
catechism‘s interpretation of the myth perpetuates the
historicist position of Humani Generis (1950), standing in
tension with broad scholarly consensus and with the
catechism‘s own endorsement of the historical-critical
method. I offer a hermeneutical critique of the catechism‘s
historicist position, drawing upon scholarly insights on the genre
of myth. Finally, I argue that the catechism‘s mode of
argumentation in defense of its historicist interpretation of the
Adamic myth, exhibits the characteristics of integralism, an
approach to Catholic doctrine that conflates magisterial
formulations with revelation itself and necessitates the
application of a hermeneutics of suspicion on the part of
catechists and learners.


A thesis submitted to the Faculty of the Candler School of
Theology in partial
fulfillment of the requirement for the degree of Master of
Theological Studies, 2012


Abstract
"Trouble in Paradise: Disharmony among Magisterial
Interpretations of the Adamic Narrative"
By Alan McGill

Title:
Islands of Memory: The Sea Islands, Black Women Artists, and the
Promise of Home
Abstract:
Abstract
Islands of Memory: The Sea Islands, Black Women Artists, and the
Promise of Home
By Folashadé Alao

This study examines the development and construction of the Sea
Islands as a
significant cultural landscape in the black imagination and
historicizes the processes
informing the Sea Islands' contemporary emergence as a site of
memory. The
coalescence of cultural and academic interests, the publication of
new research materials
on the Sea Islands, and the discovery and republication of old
works, such as Drums and
Shadows, during the 1970's enabled the Sea Islands to emerge in
the national black
imagination in new ways that black visual artists and writers would
illuminate. The
movement of Gullah culture into the mainstream and the elevation of
the Sea Islands as a
site of memory were aided particularly by literary, dramatic,
musical, and visual arts and
the sustained interests and creative expressions of different
groups of artists.
This study focuses on the particular visualizations of the Sea
Islands in Paule
Marshall's Praisesong for the Widow (1983), Gloria Naylor's
Mama Day (1988), and
Julie Dash's film Daughters of the Dust (1991) and novel
Daughters of the Dust (1997).
Specifically, I underscore the sources they draw upon to construct
their visions; the
voices, images, and histories they challenge; the functions they
hope such a vision will
hold for their readers; and their works' place within the Sea
Islands Cultural Renaissance
which surrounds their publication. Marshall, Naylor, and Dash's
works capture and
respond to a transforming relationship between African Americans
and their African
ancestry as well as to the southern landscape, both of which
resulted from the social and
political struggles of the 1960s and 1970s and a shift in black
migratory patterns in the
1970s. Marshall, Naylor, and Dash's works also reflect a renewed
critical study of
African American origins and genealogy, and the increasing concerns
surrounding the
transformations of black urban and rural life. The Sea Islands, in
these works, emerge as
a site of intersections, continuity, and reconnections with
southern homeplaces, distant
African memories, submerged oral histories, and neglected cultural
traditions.

Table of Contents -- Introduction -- 5 -- Chapter 1 -- "A Sacred
Place:" Understanding the Social, Cultural, -- 34 -- and
Demographic History of the Sea Islands -- Chapter 2 -- Paule

Praisesong for the Widow -- Chapter 3 -- "More than a family . . .
a history:" The Sea Islands as -- 119 -- a cultural landscape in
Mama Day -- Chapter 4 -- "We are as two people in one body:"
Migration(s) -- 165 -- and Recollection in Julie Dash's film
Daughters of the Dust -- Chapter 5 -- "I want to know what it is:"
Folk Narratives, Flying Africans -- 210 -- and Folk Beliefs in
